header.title: Anger at ‘hard-hitting’ film on Islamophobia is ‘ironic’, says Muslim filmmaker
header.postText: A Muslim filmmaker has said calls to ‘withdraw’ and ‘ban’ his hard-hitting film on Islamophobia, designed to tackle hate crime, are ‘ironic’ and ‘bizarre’.', 'The Martyrs, a four-minute film shot in west London in the wake of the Christchurch shootings, is based on three real-life Islamophobic crimes: a stabbing, an acid attack and the kicking in the stomach of a pregnant woman, leading to the death of her unborn twins.', 'The film has been made by Rizwan Wadan, who aims to use filmmaking as a medium through which to ‘open dialogue’ and show the impact of hate crimes by ‘taking people on a journey’ to highlight ‘violence doesn’t achieve anything’.', 'It is set against the backdrop of the ‘punish a Muslim day’ last year, in which letters were sent to homes and businesses around the country, suggesting that people could win ‘points’ for attacking Muslims.', 'He hit out at claims that his graphic film was ‘sensationalist’ or ‘promoting fear’ after receiving criticisms from groups including Tell MAMA, a charity that records anti-Muslim hate crimes.', 'Rizwan said: ‘The cases depicted in the film are real life incidents, if anything we’ve toned down the filming by not showing the full extent of the violent attack on a Muslim lady who miscarried her twins’.', 'The fimaker said the aim of hard-hitting films like the one he has made is to ‘turn confrontations into conversations’ and to get people ‘thinking about these topics’.', 'Addressing the claim that the film promotes fear he said: ‘People are worried and scared regardless, take the attacks on mosques in New Zealand, people have been sharing the video on their phones, that’s caused fear.', '‘Tell MAMA’s statistics about a 593% increase in anti-Muslim hate crimes, some could argue that promotes fear.’', 'He said his film was about ‘telling Muslim stories from a Muslim perspective’ and that film was a ‘national treasure’ through which to tell those stories and ‘show other people our world’.', 'Rizwan added that the entire message of the film was to teach ‘against violence and hatred’ and that it has received support from a broad demographic including both Muslims and non-Muslims.', 'Commenting on the idea that the film should be withdrawn or banned, he said he found it ‘shocking and bizarre’, especially since countries ‘like Saudi Arabia lifted a ban on films last year, and now in 2019, people are asking for my film to be banned’.', 'Mr Wadan said film was a key medium that he felt Muslim communities had ‘neglected’ in the fight against Islamophobia and anti-Muslim hatred, and while one of the aims of the film was to show the impact of anti-Muslim hatred from a Muslim perspective, the other was to show that film can be utilised by Muslims as a means through which to tell their own stories.', 'He added that if Muslims were ‘annoyed and angry’ at the way they are represented, then the solution is to get engaged with that medium and work with others to ‘challenge those perceptions’.', 'He also said he had made many personal sacrifices on the journey to becoming a film maker, including selling his own camera equipment worth £32,500, in order to fulfil his ambition of tackling hatred and extremism through the films.', 'A spokesperson for Tell MAMA said: ‘You can develop a film that informs, educates and puts forward the notion of how anti-Muslim hate takes place. Yet, this film has 3 aggressive plots, one of which shows a man dying and being stabbed.', '‘Whilst we know of 3 cases where Muslims have been killed by far-right extremists, aggressive cases do not make up the vast majority of hate crimes.', 'They added: ‘We are also duty bound to work to ensures that fears are not exponentially increased at this time when there are divisions taking place.’
